protest.translation[0].definitions[0].de: something that you do to show publicly that you think that something is wrong and unfair, for example taking part in big public meetings, refusing to work, or refusing to buy a company’s products
protest.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Five thousand employees came out on strike in protest at the poor working conditions.
Students held a protest march against the war.
protest.translation[0].definitions[1].de: words or actions that show that you do not want someone to do something or that you dislike something very much
protest.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: She ignored his protests and walked away.
The programme caused a storm of protest (=a lot of angry protest).
The announcement was met with howls of protest.
I turned off the TV, despite loud protests from the kids.
He accepted his punishment without protest.
protest.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: Opponents of the plan have staged several protests.
The arrests sparked off violent street protests.
She organized a protest outside the store.
Massive protests erupted across the country.
The announcement led to widespread public protests.
Lee spent five years in prison for his involvement in political protest.
Some 5,000 students and others began a peaceful protest.
Three people died yesterday in violent protests against the war.
There were mass protests in the capital.
They reacted to the king’s forced abdication with massive public protests.
Student protests were crushed by police.
There was a ban on street protests.
Religious leaders continued to lead anti-government protests.
Students at the heart of the protest movement have called for a general strike.
They staged a protest march through the city’s streets.
A protest rally in the capital was attended by about 400 people.
protest.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to come together to publicly express disapproval or opposition to something
protest.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Thousands of people blocked the street, protesting against the new legislation.
protest.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to say that you strongly disagree with or are angry about something because you think it is wrong or unfair
protest.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: ‘I don’t see why I should take the blame for this!’ she protested.
Clive protested that he hadn’t been given enough time to do everything.
protest.translation[1].definitions[2].de: to state very firmly that something is true, when other people do not believe you
protest.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: Years later, he is still protesting his innocence.
Sarah protested that she wasn’t Mick’s girlfriend.
protest.translation[1].note_box[0].secti: protest
to do something to show publicly that you disagree with something – used especially when a large group of people do this together
Huge crowds gathered in the capital protesting against the war.
Drivers blocked roads around the capital to protest about the rising cost of fuel.
march
to walk in a large group from one place to another in order to protest about something
Hundreds of students marched through the city in protest against the employment laws.
demonstrate
to walk or stand somewhere in a large group, in order to protest about something
About 200 people were demonstrating outside the US Embassy.
Environmentalists have been demonstrating against plans to dump waste at sea.
riot
to protest by behaving in a violent and uncontrolled way
Hundreds of workers rioted after pay negotiations broke down.
The prisoners were rioting against their appalling conditions.
boycott
to protest about the actions of a company, country, or industry by refusing to buy something, or refusing to go to a place or event
They may boycott the next Olympic Games.
Shoppers are boycotting battery-farmed eggs.
hold/stage a sit-in
to protest by refusing to leave a place
The students have been staging a sit-in to protest about overcrowding at the polytechnic.
go on a hunger strike
to protest by refusing to eat
Maynard went on a hunger strike to protest his innocence.
protest.translation[2].definitions[0].de: an angry complaint that shows you disagree with something, or when you state publicly that you think something is wrong or unfair
protest.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: The union is making a formal protest to the government about the matter.
Miners staged a two-hour strike in protest against the effects of the economic reforms.
Health workers marched on Nov. 17 in protest at government restrictions on health service expenditure.
protest.translation[2].definitions[1].de: an occasion when people meet together in public to express disapproval or opposition to something
protest.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: 17,000 demonstrators took part in a student protest against education loans.
Later this month, protest marches are planned by farmers’ groups.
protest.translation[2].definitions[2].de: unwillingly, and with the feeling that you have been unfairly treated
protest.translation[2].definitions[2].ex: I only signed the document under protest.
The tax demand was disputed by the company, and the payments were made under protest.
protest.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to show publicly that you disagree with something you think is wrong or unfair
protest.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: People always protest against new forms of taxation.
protest.translation[3].definitions[1].de: to say or do something publicly to show that you disagree with something you think is wrong or unfair
protest.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: About 40,000 angry Connecticut residents gathered outside the Capitol in Hartford to protest a new income tax.
protest.translation[3].definitions[2].de: to state very firmly that something is true, especially when other people do not believe you
protest.translation[3].definitions[2].ex: The AFL-CIO’s Richard Sawyer protested that thousands of local jobs may be lost to Mexico if the trade agreement is approved.
